description.narrative: The project objective is to safeguarding rural communities and their physical assets from climate induced disasters in Timor-Leste. To increasing the climate resilience of vulnerable small-scale rural infrastructure.

sector.narrative: Eradicate poverty in all its forms and dimensions

condition.narrative: Social and environmental sustainability will be enhanced through application of the UNDP Social and Environmental Standards (http://www.undp.org/ses) and related Accountability Mechanism (http://www.undp.org/secu-srm).

description.narrative: - # of hazard risk maps and information developed and adopted/ embedded into sectoral policies and legislations - # of infrastructure units built to new climate resilient standards - # Hectares of agroforestry implemented in target infrastructure catchments

comment.narrative: An assessment of the impact of climate-induced hydro-meteorological hazards on Timor-Leste shows that, under climate change, there will be an increase in the number of areas and key infrastructure affected for all hazards. In most cases, at least a doubling of hazard-affected areas in percentage terms is expected. 3 On average, the increase in impact of each hazard between the baseline and climate change scenarios nationally is 26.3%, 21%, 55.4%, and 55.8% for landslides, floods, erosion, and drought risk, respectively. The economic losses that could occur under climate change range from USD $203 Million, $37 Million, $10 Million, and $12.5 Million for landslides, floods, erosion, and droughts, respectively.

- 2 training on Geographical information System (GIS) and bio engineering to technical staff and local contractors; - Baseline Assessment/survey to selected municipality to assess 130 units of infrastructure;

- Training on GIS concluded - Baseline survey : The in-depth baseline assessment that was conducted has provided detail information required to validate the indicators and information and assumptions from the project design stage. The approach and activity done to re-assess the baseline situation, review established indicators, interim and final targets set by the project was comprehensive and done at national and sub-national levels and in the communities were selected for the specific project interventions. In terms of the changes in the baseline situation, the results framework has been updated with the revised baseline indicators and targets. While most of the baseline and targets remain without any major revision the most significant is with regard to outcome 2. Specifically, on indicator 2.2 “Number of infrastructure units built to new climate resilient standards” the target is set at 130 units, comprising 38 water supply systems, 25 irrigation systems, 20 flood protection and 47 units of rural roads to be built. The baseline findings revealed that there is a difference in the unit lengths (kilometers) of roads to be implemented. The target for roads to be measured against unit lengths (kilometers) of rural roads implemented to climate proofed standards as per the budgetary allocation for 186 km or road at the time of project design. In terms of the other indicators such as indicator 2.2, “No of Hectares of agroforestry implemented in target infrastructure catchments” the baseline value has been updated but the mid-term and final targets remains the same at Mid-term – 75 hectares and 300 hectares by the end of the project respectively.

1). 2-Training of Trainers (ToT) were completed namely 1) ToT on GIS-based asset condition inspection methods and tools, and 2) ToT on the use of GPS and drones to undertake topographic surveys. 2) Awarded contract to international consultancy from to develop the countrywide multi-hazard mapping and risk assessment (MHRA) and development of the GIS based risk model for Timor-Leste. 3). Conducted technical assessment to 16 units non-climate proofed infrastructure in each of the 6 target municipalities. 9 units funded under GCF fund and 7 funded under government co-financing ; 4). Conducted Assessment for nurseries in 6-municipalities to support for the catchment management activities 5). 4 Hectares of agroforestry implemented in target infrastructure catchments in Liquica Municipalities 6). Completed training to Managers and municipal engineers in climate design resilient infrastructure design using new Community Based Adaptation (CBA) ; 7). Baseline video launched

1. The first ToT was completed with the aims to introduce and develop the skills of the target participants who will become Trainers in asset mapping using GIS-based asset condition inspection methods and tools. A total of 67 participants (12% women) successfully completed the training and subsequently became co-trainers both at national and municipalities to support deliver the same training to other participants in municipalities, Administrative Posts (APs) and village level . Secondly, the ToT on the use of Global Positioning Systems (GPS) and drones to undertake topographic surveys was also concluded. The objective of the the training is to develop the skills of the target participants to undertake topographic surveys in order for them to be able to produce and update risk maps and calibrate and validate hazard maps. A total of 55 participants (13% women) not only successfully completed the training but also were selected to become co-trainers. The selected co-trainers have delivered, and will be continuing to deliver, similar training to technical staff at Administrative Posts (APs) and village levels as well as to support them with data collection for the purpose of improving the planning and development of Sucos/villages. Based on the current numbers of co-trainers, the capacity is in place to continue and support with similar trainings/activities in the coming years at national and their respective municipalities.
2. - A consultancy firm was recruited and fully onboard during Q4 to undertake a comprehensive countrywide (all 12 municipalities and Oecusses Special Economic Zone) mapping of the major climate hazards and to develop the comprehensive risk profiles and a GIS based risk model for Timor-Leste. The hazard and risk maps will be used for risk-informed decision-making for all aspects of development and risk management in the future. The kick-off meeting was initiated on 1st December 2021 and followed by a virtual inception workshop on 9th December 2021. The assignment will be completed within a period of one year starting from November 2021 to November 2022. 3). the field assessment conducted, to identified and prioritized 16-rural infrastructures to be built by 2021. There are 9-rural infrastructures from GCF grant and 7-rural infrastructures from the government co-financing with benefited to 29,141 (14,528 female, 14,612 male) in six municipalities. The prioritization of these infrastructures is based on community needs to support the movement, access to clean water and sanitation , access to public facility and markets. 4). the project conducted preliminary assessment to identified and mapping out of nurseries and local trees in each municipality and found existing 52 groups and identified 30-species of local trees. This activity aims to identify the availability of local resources at each location to support catchment management activities. However, the activities have been delayed in the procure-ment process, the project will expedite the process so that in parallel with the implementation of construction in the coming years to meet its target. 5).The project has identified 4-ha of agroforestry intervention in one location in Liquica Municipality. The land owner agreed to plant and protect above-mentioned hectares to plant different type of economic trees to pro-tect community houses, infrastructure and land , the activity eventually will support and enhance income gen-eration, environment protection to combat climate change risk. 6). - Training to Municipal Managers in investment planning optioneering, project appraisal methods and development of long-term investment planning was concluded in two-clusters with the high participation from the President of Authorities, Administrators, Deputy Administrators, Directors, Chief of Departments from relevant counterparts and Administrators from Administrative Posts. The first cluster of workshop was conducted on 29-30 July 2021 in Gleno, Ermera Municipality (covered Ermera, Liquica and Aileu municipalities) and continue to Cluster 2 on 5 – 6 August 2021 –Baucau Municipality (covered Baucau, Lautem and Viqueque municipalities). The workshop was combined with classroom presentation and field visit in Suco Lauala, Ermera and Suco Buruma, Baucau respectively where the participants being able to participated basic training on climate resilient infrastructure approaches, used of GPS and drones and social and environmental safeguards . A total 117 (3 female ) participated in Cluster A and Cluster B during two days training. 7). - Under the communication plan, a total of 1, 500 brochures, baseline video have been developed and distributed. The baseline video and brochures to be disseminated to all the relevant stakeholders to help raise awareness about the challenges due to climate change and the changes in terms of mainstreaming climate change into infrastructure planning and development at the local level. VIdio: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fKDdBh3lNJw .

1. Conducting Mapping Hazard Risk Assessment (MHRA) in 90 sucos in 6 municipalities. Countrywide multi-hazard risk assessment undertaken and the comprehensive climate hazard mapping carried out and multi-hazard climate risk model developed including at least the 4 main hazards such as landslides, erosion, flooding, drought. 2. Construct 30 units of climate resilient small-scale rural infrastructure. Priority this year 5 Rural Roads (RR) and 4 Irrigation System (IS) in location as follow:  A-RR-05 in suco Lahae, post administration Aileu Villa, municipal Aileu  B-RR-06 in suco Lavateri, post administration Baguia, municipal Baucau  L-RR-01 in suco Lauhata, post administration Bazartete, municipal Liquica  L-RR-06 in suco Lisadila, post administration Maubara, municipal Liquica  La-RR-04 in suco Bauro, post administration Lospalos, municipal Lautem  B-IS-07 in suco Fatulia, post administration Venilale, Municipal Baucau  E-IS-04 in suco Malabe, post administration Atsabe, municipal Ermera  V-IS-01 in suco Uaniuma, post administration Uatucarbau, municipal Viqueque  V-IS-03 in suco Matahoi, post administration Uatulari, municipal Viqueque 3. Implement Climate Resilient Infrastructure Methods (CRIM) through activities:  Implement soil bioengineering selected area in 6 municipalities.  Implement agroforestry total 300 hectares in selected suco cross 6 municipalities (Aileu, Baucau, Ermera, Liquica, Lautem and Viqueque) At least 75 hectares of vulnerable landscape restored and under agroforestry, bioengineering and reforestation benefitting 23,412 Household. 4. Conduct Physical Asset Mapping (PAM), Georeferenced Point and completed sanitation Mapping in 6 municipalities 5. National and sub-national DRM capacities strengthened, and at least 2 national strategies methodologies and guidelines developed/adopted for Climate Resilient infrastructure 6. Delivery TOT GIS system, Contractor and MHRA. At least 200 staff in MSA, MI-SSCP and MAF trained and using new tools and technologies that help to safeguard communities and their physical assets against climate induced disasters,
